CatDescriptText: Mr. Henry Jones, laborer, Uptown and Mr. Nathaniel R. McIntosh, heavy equipment operator, Uptown, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 20, 1960, pg. A1 with question: "Do you believe fares would be lower and service better on trolleys and buses if the city owned and operated these services?"  Mr. Jones' answer reads: "I don't know whether or not the fares would be cheaper and the service better, because Pittsburgh is a racket town."  Mr. McIntosh's answer reads: "In Philadelphia, Washington, and other cities throughout the country, the fares are cheaper.  So therefore, I think that if Pittsburgh like the other cities operated the trolleys and buses, the rates would be cheaper."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Henry Jones wearing thin moustache and cap, standing in front of brick building; Portrait of Nathaniel R. McIntosh wearing dark fedora and dark patterned polo shirt, posed in front of brick building
